Award.AwardTitle: UNS: Collaborative Research: Numerical/Experimental Investigation of Solar Chimney Power Plants

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
1510179(Gross) & 1510717(Fasel)

The goal of this proposal is to investigate the fluid dynamics processes that occur in solar chimney plants, in order to enable their use at a large scale. In solar chimney power plants, air under a circular collector is heated by the sun. The hot air rises through a central chimney and the resulting thermal convection drives turbines at the inflow to the chimney. Large-scale plants could provide electricity at a competitive cost, but the fluid dynamics involved are not well understood. Such research in energy generation is of National interest.

The fluid dynamics process that plays a dominant role here is the radial Rayleigh-Benard-Poiseuille flow. The proposed work is about understanding of the instabilities for inward and outward radial Rayleigh-Benard-Poiseuille flow that will advance the science of primary and secondary instability with convection, but in addition, this understanding can help the informed design of solar chimney power plants. As part of this research project the flow instabilities governing laminar, transitional, and turbulent inward radial Rayleigh-Benard-Poiseuille flow will be explored. Towards this end, computer simulations will be carried out for investigating the primary and secondary instabilities and their role in the evolution and dynamics of flow structures that affect both heat transfer and streamwise pressure drop in the collector. For the laminar and transitional regime, the simulation strategies will be validated by experiments using scientifically instrumented scaled solar chimney models. Once validated, the Reynolds number of the simulations will be increased to investigate the instabilities of the turbulent flow in full-size solar chimney collectors. Both the University of Arizona and New Mexico State University have a large body of Hispanic and Native American students who can form a diverse pool of candidate students who will work in this research. The project will allow the continuation of an already established high school outreach program. In addition, a website will be created to inform the public about the project, to post daily operating data of the demonstrator, and to share results with other researchers.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Solar chimney power plants promise to become a viable sustainable alternative to existing fossil and solar power plants. For such plants, the radial air flow under a circular collector is heated by the sun light. The hot air rises through a central chimney. The resulting natural convection drives turbines at the foot of the chimney and sucks in air from the perimeter of the collector. The technology has never been realized on a larger scale mainly because the unknowns (in particular with respect to the fluid dynamics of the radial collector) are considered too large which makes the technology too risky for investment.

During day time operation, the collector bottom wall temperature is above the top wall temperature. When the bottom wall heating is strong enough, the heated air develops enough buoyancy to overcome its own weight. In that case, instability of the flow can lead to counter-rotating streamwise flow structures that greatly increase mixing in the wall-normal direction. Numerical simulations of the radial flow were carried out to understand the naturally occurring instabilities that can lead to large-scaled flow structures.

The understanding of the instabilities gained from the simulations is of significance for academia and industry: It provides a foundation for future experiments and analytical analyses. It allows designers to determine if and how buoyancy-driven instabilities affect the performance of solar chimney power plants. The improved understanding of the fluid dynamics of solar chimney power plants will bolster investor confidence and hopefully lead the way towards the installation of a large-scale prototype that is ultimately needed for the validation of the technology.

The research activities provided training for a graduate and an undergraduate student. Through the training of graduate and undergraduate students the project made a contribution to the development of the future work force in science and sustainable engineering.
